item.title: U.S. Charges New Suspect in Haiti President’s Murder, Widening Investigation
item.description: The case could help U.S. prosecutors get closer to the people who plotted the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse of Haiti.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: The funeral of President Jovenel Moïse in July.

item.title: U.N. Approves Israeli Measure to Condemn Holocaust Denial
item.description: The resolution was aimed at combating what Israel and other countries have described as an epidemic of disinformation about the murder of nearly six million Jews and millions of others by the Nazis.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: The ‘Hall of Names’ at the Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial museum on the eve of Holocaust Remembrance Day last year in Jerusalem.

item.title: A Trove of Old Photos Could Reveal the Future of These Arctic Glaciers
item.description: The Svalbard Islands, part of Norway, are warming seven times faster than the global average. Aerial pictures from the 1930s are helping researchers understand what that means for the region’s ice.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong

item.title: In Peru, Courts ‘Used Like Whips’ to Silence Journalists
item.description: The author of a book about a powerful politician has been sentenced to two years in prison. Media advocates say the case is part of a trend in which the courts are being used to punish critics.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Mitra Taj
item.media:credit: Angela Ponce for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Peruvian journalist Christopher Acosta has been sentenced to two years in prison and, with his publisher, fined $100,000 following a defamation lawsuit brought by a powerful politician.

item.title: Ingrid Betancourt to Make a Bid for President of Colombia
item.description: Ingrid Betancourt’s candidacy comes at a critical time, when Colombians are fed up with the political establishment and the future of the peace agreement is at stake.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.media:credit: Nathalia Angarita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ingrid Betancourt, the politician and former FARC hostage, said she would run for president. Her bid comes as the country is at a critical crossroads.

item.title: Why a Stranded Barge Has Become a Popular Vancouver Photo Spot
item.description: Washed ashore during a fierce November storm, a massive barge has become both a popular sightseeing spot and meme in Vancouver.
item.dc:creator: Gerald Narciso
item.media:credit: Martin Tessler for The New York Times
item.media:description: The beached barge is a favorite spot to take selfies in Vancouver. It crashed ashore during a November storm, initially raising fear that it might collide with the Burrard Bridge, a historic, four-lane truss bridge in the background.

item.title: Tonga Shrouded by Ash and Mystery After Powerful Volcano Erupts
item.description: So far, the only deaths reported occurred 6,000 miles away, in Peru. But outside emergency workers have yet to make their way to the Pacific island nation.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost, Mitra Taj and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: National Institute of Information and Communications Technology (NICT), via Associated Press
item.media:description: A satellite image showing the undersea volcano eruption, right, off the Pacific nation of Tonga.

item.title: Ontario Town Still Searching for Answers in Gas Leak Explosion
item.description: Hundreds of people in Wheatley, Ontario, are still out of their homes four months after a gas leak blew up three buildings in the town’s center.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The center of Wheatley, Ontario, has been closed off since August.

item.title: Mass Trials in Cuba Deepen Its Harshest Crackdown in Decades
item.description: Following nationwide demonstrations last year, more than 60 people were put on trial this week, some facing up to 30 years behind bars.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Oscar Lopez
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Thousands of Cubans demonstrated in Havana in July.

item.title: Journalists in El Salvador Targeted With Spyware Intended for Criminals
item.description: The announcement came months after the U.S. government blacklisted the Israeli firm that produces Pegasus, the technology used to target the journalists.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Spyware has been found on the phones of 22 reporters and editors from the El Faro newspaper in El Salvador over the last year.

item.title: Miami-Bound Passenger Storms Cockpit in Honduras, Causing Flight Delay
item.description: As the American Airlines flight was boarding on Tuesday afternoon, the passenger entered the cockpit and “caused damage,” the airline said.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: Airlines have had to deal with thousands of cancellations and delays in recent months.

item.title: Citigroup seeks a split from a Mexico business that brought it riches and scandal.
item.description: The business, known as Banamex, has generated heavy regulatory scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Emily Flitter
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Citi bought Banco Nacional de México, better known as Banamex, in 2001 for $12.5 billion.

item.title: Source of Mysterious Gas Leak Explosion in Canadian Town Stumps Officials
item.description: An explosion last summer in an Ontario community built on 19th-century gas wells has left locals searching for answers and some certainty that their town will ever recover.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Tara Walton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Wheatley, Ontario, where a large gas explosion last August destroyed three buildings.

item.title: Haitian Prime Minister Had Close Links With Murder Suspect
item.description: New evidence suggests the man who took over from Haiti’s murdered president had close links to a prime suspect in the assassination — and that the two stayed in contact even after the crime.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Jovenel Moïse, who was assassinated in July, led Haiti by decree and turned to authoritarian tactics.

item.title: Cliff Collapses on Boaters in Brazil, Killing 10
item.description: The tragedy in Minas Gerais state gripped the nation because it was captured on videos that showed an immense slab of rock smashing into pleasure boats.
item.dc:creator: Ernesto Londoño
item.media:description: A canyon in Lake Furnas, near Capitólio in southeast Brazil.

item.title: The James Webb Telescope Finishes Deployment in Space
item.description: Everything is going great for the James Webb Space Telescope. So far.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye and Joey Roulette
item.media:description: An artist’s concept of the fully deployed and unfolded James Webb Space Telescope, which is currently on its way to a spot called L2, where it will orbit the sun. It is now 600,000 miles from Earth.

item.title: BlackBerry Phone Service Officially Ends
item.description: BlackBerry was once Canada’s most valuable company and a global force in tech. The final step in its downfall as a phone maker arrived this week.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: A BlackBerry poster at a trade fair in Hanover, Germany, in 2008.

item.title: Covid Cases Reach Pandemic High at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: The American base has reinstated a mandate for wearing masks indoors in response to an increase in infections.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.media:description: Members of the American military waiting for their turn to be vaccinated at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba in September. Infections at the base have reached a pandemic high.

item.title: Airlines Strand Passengers Who Partied on Flight Without Masks
item.description: A group of Canadian social media influencers and others flouted Covid-19 rules on a flight to Cancún, Mexico, resulting in airlines leaving many of them without a way home.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: Maskless Canadian passengers partied on a Sunwing Airlines plane. Now they are being investigated for violating the country’s aviation rules and Covid restrictions.

item.title: How Many Bagels Does It Take to Keep a Place in Business?
item.description: Two quintessential bagel shops dish on the business of selling lots and lots of bagels.
item.dc:creator: Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg

item.title: Dozens Die in Church Stampede in Liberia
item.description: Worshipers were gathered for a revival meeting in the Liberian capital, when word of armed gang members robbing people set off deadly panic.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Daniel Nyakonah
item.media:description: People search through piles of shoes left in a panicked stampede in Monrovia, Liberia, that left 29 people dead.

item.title: Mining Truck Explodes in Ghana, Killing Dozens
item.description: The number of dead is not yet known, but the blast flattened buildings in a small town and left a large crater.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean, Philip Nii Lartey, Elian Peltier and Joseph Quayson

item.title: This ‘Plastic Man’ Has a Cape and a Superhero’s Mission: Cleaning Up Senegal
item.description: Dressed head to toe in plastic, Modou Fall is a familiar sight in Dakar. But however playful his costume, his goal couldn’t be more serious: ridding the capital of the scourge of plastic bags.
item.dc:creator: Mady Camara and Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Ricci Shryock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Modou Fall, who works to educate fellow Senegalase residents about the dangers of plastic trash, making his case at the annual marathon in Dakar, Senegal, in November.

item.title: Sudan’s Security Forces Kill Protesters as U.S. Diplomats’ Visit Nears
item.description: Seven people died after being shot at demonstrations in the northeast African country, a doctors’ group said, bringing the civilian death toll since the military seized back power to 71.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Protesters took to the streets of Sudan’s capital, Khartoum, on Monday to demand a return to civilian rule.

item.title: The Eerie, Lunar Nothingness of Namibia’s Skeleton Coast
item.description: The stretch of coastline in southwest Africa is a strange and beautiful reminder that, in the end, we are powerless against nature and time.
item.dc:creator: Genna Martin
item.media:description: The C34 highway, along Namibia’s coast, is barely distinguishable from the surrounding desert.

item.title: Ibrahim Boubacar Keita, Malian President Ousted in 2020, Dies at 76
item.description: Mr. Keita was elected in 2013 with a mandate to stem the country’s many crises. But during his tenure, they escalated.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ibrahim Boubacar Keita at the United Nations in New York in 2019. He came to power after a coup, and was ousted after another.

item.title: FIFA's Best? Pitso Mosimane Doesn't Fit the Model
item.description: Pitso Mosimane enjoyed a better 2021 than almost any coach in world soccer. Just don’t expect FIFA, or soccer, to notice.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Pitso Mosimane with the African Super Cup, one of the three continental titles he won with Al Ahly in 2021.

item.title: Pause in Zimbabwe Trial of Freelance Reporter for The Times
item.description: The trial of Jeffrey Moyo, accused of having fabricated accreditation cards for two New York Times journalists, will resume next month.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeffrey Moyo leaving the courtroom earlier this week in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, with his wife, Purity, in pink dress.

item.title: Nigeria Lifts Twitter Ban
item.description: The social media site had been blocked after it deleted a post from President Muhammadu Buhari about secessionist groups that was widely seen as threatening.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Mohammadu Buhari of Nigeria in December. Some saw his tweet as a threat against the Igbo ethnic group.

item.title: Cameroon's Goalkeeper André Onana Just Wants to Play
item.description: Cameroon’s 25-year-old goalkeeper has already had his career interrupted twice by bans. Now he’s back, and eager to move on.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: André Onana, pride of Cameroon’s Indomitable Lions.

item.title: Car Bomb in Mogadishu, Somalia's Capital, Kills 8
item.description: The explosion, one of a string of recent attacks, comes as the country grapples with a political standoff and a growing humanitarian crisis.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: The scene of a car bombing in Mogadishu, Somalia, on Wednesday. A news site associated with Al Shabab said the militant group had carried out the attack.

item.title: On Day Biden Calls Ethiopia’s Leader to Urge Peace, a Drone Strike Kills 17
item.description: The attack came days after over 50 people were killed in a strike on a refugee camp, highlighting the growing role of armed drones in a destructive war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.media:description: Survivors of an air strike by Ethiopian government forces at a hospital in the town of Dedebit, in the northern region of Tigray, Ethiopia, on Saturday.

item.title: Suspect in South Africa’s Parliament Fire Is Sent for Psychiatric Check
item.description: If the man is found fit to stand trial, he will face charges that now include terrorism. His lawyers said he would protest with a hunger strike.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Zandile Christmas Mafe, who is suspected of setting the fire that tore through South Africa’s Parliament buildings, appeared in court in Cape Town on Tuesday.

item.title: In South Africa, Success Against H.I.V. Offers Hope
item.description: A former Africa correspondent, who covered the height of the AIDS epidemic there 15 years ago, finds lessons in the remarkable progress against that virus for our current fight.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A near-empty ward of the Chongwe District Hospital outside Lusaka, Zambia. Fifteen years ago, a hospital like this would have been overflowing with H.I.V. patients lying two or three to a bed.

item.title: Freelance Reporter for the New York Times Is On Trial in Zimbabwe
item.description: The reporter, Jeffrey Moyo, has been accused of helping two Times journalists enter Zimbabwe from South Africa using bogus credentials, a charge that even the government admits is on ‘shaky ground.’
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeffrey Moyo, second from left, conferring with his lawyers, Doug Coltart and Beatrice Mtetwa, outside the courtroom in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe, on Tuesday, as Mr. Moyo’s wife, Purity, second from right, listens. Mr. Moyo’s trial begins on Wednesday.

item.title: Uganda Reopens Schools After World’s Longest Covid Shutdown
item.description: Many countries have closed classrooms on and off, but Uganda had kept more than 10 million students at home since March 2020. Critics say it took a heavy toll.
item.dc:creator: Musinguzi Blanshe and Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children back in class at Kitante Primary School in Kampala, Uganda, on Monday.

item.title: Jawar Mohammed to Be Released From Prison by Ethiopian President
item.description: Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed declared the amnesty on Orthodox Christmas and offered to start a dialogue with some opponents after 14 months of war.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Oromos calling for the release of prominent opposition figures in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, in October.

item.title: In ‘African Origin’ Show at Met, New Points of Light Across Cultures
item.description: Holdings from Ancient Egypt and sub-Saharan Africa come together in a masterpiece show. Now the Met should make clear how the wondrous works got here.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.media:credit: Seth Caplan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Partnerships: Spanning eras and cultures, a pairing of artworks from “The African Origin of Civilization” includes “The King’s Acquaintances Memi and Sabu” from Egypt, ca. 2575–2465 B.C. and “Seated Couple” from Mali, 18th or early 19th century.

item.title: Mystery Deepens as Suspect Is Charged in South Africa Parliament Fire
item.description: The man was also accused of possessing explosives, stealing laptops and breaking security laws. Former neighbors were shocked. His lawyer said the government was rushing to find a scapegoat.
item.dc:creator: Zanele Mji and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Zandile Christmas Mafe was charged with arson, theft and housebreaking in connection with the fire.

item.title: Sudan Braces for ‘the Worst’ after Prime Minister Resigns
item.description: With the departure of the civilian prime minister Abdalla Hamdok on Sunday, the military and security forces are now fully in control of Sudan again.

item.media:description: People chant slogans during a protest to denounce the October 2021 military coup, in Khartoum on Sunday.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Tougher Words on Russia
item.description: The West stressed a unified response after Biden’s stumble.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: The Ukrainian military on the front line of Katerynivka, in the Luhansk Oblast province of eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Drops Its Case Against M.I.T. Scientist Accused of Hiding China Links
item.description: Gang Chen, a professor of mechanical engineering, was arrested a year ago, accused of concealing his affiliations with Chinese government institutions.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry and Katie Benner
item.media:description: Gang Chen, an M.I.T. scientist, was arrested in 2021 as part of the China Initiative, a government anti-espionage effort that has come under criticism for singling out scientists of Chinese heritage.

item.title: Zara Rutherford Becomes Youngest Woman to Circle the Globe Solo
item.description: When Zara Rutherford landed on Thursday, she became the youngest woman to circumnavigate the globe solo. “I’m just happy to finally also be in the same spot for a few months,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Zara Rutherford greets supporters after landing at an airport in Kortrijk, Belgium, on Thursday.

item.title: Lockdown Made Their Second Date Last Weeks. Would Romance Bloom?
item.description: Sparks didn’t fly on their first blind date. Then the city shut down while she was visiting.

item.title: This Ancient Brew Has Retro Appeal in South Korea
item.description: Makgeolli, a rice wine made by Korean farmers for centuries, has become a cosmopolitan sensation over the past decade. The buzz grew during Covid lockdowns.

item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Han A-young, the owner of Hanayangjo, labelling bottles of makgeolli she made in Seoul, in June.

item.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
item.description: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

item.title: Ash From Tonga Volcanic Eruption Still Poses a Threat
item.description: Ash from a volcanic eruption in the South Pacific nation presents risks to drinking water and air quality, experts say. Quantifying them in real time is a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Eric Nagourney
item.media:credit: New Zealand Defence Force, via Reuters
item.media:description: Heavy ash fell over Nomuka, Tonga, as seen from a New Zealand military surveillance flight on Monday.

item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, right, met Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, in Kyiv on Wednesday.

item.title: Drone Strike Video Shows Killing of Civilians in Afghanistan
item.description: The New York Times obtained footage of the botched strike in Kabul, whose victims included seven children, through a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit.

item.title: Belgium Convicts 18 in People-Smuggling Case Tied to U.K. Truck Deaths
item.description: A Belgian court convicted a man said to have been the leader of a human trafficking operation that resulted in the deaths of 39 Vietnamese migrants in 2019. More than a dozen others were also found guilty.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: The bodies were discovered in a truck parked at Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, east of London, more than two years ago.

item.title: Japan places Tokyo and 12 other prefectures under a quasi-state of emergency because of Omicron.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida
item.media:description: Tokyo last week. Thirteen additional prefectures in Japan will be placed under a quasi-state of emergency because of a rise in Omicron cases.

item.title: China's Rising Menace Hardens Taiwan's Separate Identity
item.description: More than ever, Taiwan defines itself by its democratic values. Beijing’s military and diplomatic threats only reinforce the island’s separateness.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Li Yuan-hsin, right, with her husband and daughter at a day care center in Chiayi, Taiwan. Ms. Li is among the more than 60 percent of the island’s people who identify as solely Taiwanese.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Race to Dominate the Metaverse
item.description: Microsoft said it planned to buy the video game company Activision Blizzard for nearly $70 billion.

item.media:description: Playing Call of Duty: Black Ops at Paris Games Week in 2018.

item.description: The Golden State Warriors distanced themselves from a minority stakeholder, Chamath Palihapitiya, who said “nobody cares” about the Uyghurs, the ethnic group that has faced a deadly crackdown in China.

item.title: Hong Kong Will Cull Thousands of Hamsters After Covid Cases
item.description: Officials said it was not clear that the virus had been transmitted to humans from the animals. But they called on residents to surrender recently imported hamsters.

item.title: Ricardo Bofill, Architect of Otherworldly Buildings, Dies at 82

item.title: Syrian Doctor Accused of Atrocities Goes on Trial in Germany
item.description: The charges against Alaa Mousa include torturing opponents of the Assad regime in military hospitals in Syria, and murdering at least one by lethal injection.

Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A Syrian doctor, Alaa Mousa, went on trial in Frankfurt, Germany, on Wednesday, charged with torturing opponents of the Syrian regime and murdering one of them.

item.title: Gaspard Ulliel, 37, 'Moon Knight' and 'Hannibal Rising' Star, Dies Skiing
item.description: He gained fame as a young Hannibal Lecter and the designer Yves Saint Laurent. He died after a skiing accident weeks before he is to appear in a Disney+ series.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Gaspard Ulliel in 2019. “His sensitivity and the intensity of his acting” made him “an exceptional actor,” the French culture minister said.

item.title: A Trove of Old Photos Could Reveal the Future of These Arctic Glaciers
item.description: The Svalbard Islands, part of Norway, are warming seven times faster than the global average. Aerial pictures from the 1930s are helping researchers understand what that means for the region’s ice.

item.title: Court in Ukraine Declines Request to Arrest Former President
item.description: A feud between President Volodymyr Zelensky and his predecessor, Petro O. Poroshenko, has carried on despite the risk the country is facing from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

item.title: Undeterred by Omicron, Tourists Seek Sun in a Welcoming Spain
item.description: For decades, Spain has been a prime destination for European snowbirds. Even as the Omicron variant spreads, the country is keeping its doors wide open to visitors.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Casey and José Bautista
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists watching the sunset from a vantage point on Lanzarote, one of the Canary Islands.

item.title: Silvio Berlusconi Angles for Italy’s Presidency, Bunga Bunga and All
item.description: The billionaire former prime minister is working hard to persuade lawmakers to vote for him next week, despite an unusual résumé for a job resting on moral authority.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi in Milan in October.

item.title: The U.S. Bombed a Dam in Syria That Was on a ‘No-Strike’ List
item.description: A military report warned that striking the giant structure could cause tens of thousands of deaths.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps, Azmat Khan and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: A worker at the Tabqa Dam in 2017.

item.title: Palestinian American Died Handcuffed in Israeli Custody, Witnesses Say
item.description: Omar Assad, 78, had hoped to see his children in the U.S. one more time. Instead he died after being detained by Israeli soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: The funeral for Omar Assad, 78, who died after he was detained by Israeli soldiers, in Jiljilya last week.

item.title: Kamal Mouzawak Is Championing Lebanon's Culinary Traditions
item.description: At home and now in Paris, Kamal Mouzawak empowers Lebanese communities through food. Not even the horrific port blast in 2020 has stopped him.

item.title: Russia and Iran Put on a Show of Unity — Against the U.S.

item.description: The charges against Alaa Mousa include torturing opponents of the Assad regime in military hospitals in Syria, and murdering at least one by lethal injection.

Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Israel Evicts Palestinians in Sheikh Jarrah Area of Jerusalem
item.description: Israelis evicted an extended family and destroyed their homes in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood, where attempted evictions last year helped spark a war with Gaza.

item.title: A fourth shot may not offer much more protection against catching Omicron, an early Israeli study suggests.
item.description: The small study adds information to the debate over whether a fourth shot is advisable.

item.media:description: A resident receives a fourth dose of the coronavirus vaccine at a nursing home in Tel Mond, Israel, earlier this month.

item.title: Yemen’s Houthi Militia Claims Rare Military Strike on U.A.E.

item.media:description: An Abu Dhabi National Oil Company storage facility on Monday.

item.title: Israeli Artist Turns Plastic Pollution Into ‘Earth Poetica’

item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beverly Barkat in her Jerusalem studio assembling “Earth Poetica,” a huge globe, from plastic waste. Its permanent home will be a building at ground zero in Manhattan.

item.title: A Ban on 19 Singers in Egypt Tests the Old Guard’s Power
item.description: Leaders of a musicians’ licensing group are trying to curb mahraganat, a bold genre wildly popular with young people. It is not clear if they can.

item.media:description: Mahraganat music played at a bachelor party in 2019 in Cairo, where the genre is very popular.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Lawyers Discuss a Plea Bargain to End His Graft Trial
item.description: Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s former prime minister, has pleaded not guilty in a corruption case. But his lawyers are negotiating a deal in which he might accept some charges to avoid jail time.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: Benjamin Netanyahu at a hearing in Jerusalem in November. The talks are the latest twist in a legal process that began in 2016 after claims that Mr. Netanyahu had accepted gifts in exchange for political favors.

item.title: 32 Years After Civil War, Mundane Moments Trigger Awful Memories
item.description: Cards. Candles. Sunsets. For this New York Times correspondent and other children of Beirut in the 1980s, traumatic reminders of the war are still there in everyday activities.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Everyday items like candles can trigger traumatic memories of the war. As sweeping power outages in Beirut continue, residents have once again found themselves living by candlelight.

item.title: Oil Prices Stay High as Output From OPEC and Others Falls Behind

item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: An oil refinery in Port Arthur, Texas. Lagging production of oil worldwide has been sending prices to seven-year highs and driving inflation.

item.title: Majid Al Futtaim, Who Helped Build Modern Dubai, Dies at 87

item.title: First Trial for Syrian State Atrocities Yields Guilty Verdict in Germany

item.media:description: The former Syrian intelligence officer Anwar Raslan in the courtroom on Thursday in Koblenz, Germany.

item.title: Palestinian American Dies of Heart Attack After Brief Detention by Israeli Troops

item.title: Aras Amiri Has Returned to the U.K. After Being Jailed in Iran

item.title: Saudi Princess Is Released, but Other Royals Are Still Locked Up

item.media:description: Princess Basmah bint Saud in Washington in 2017 during a discussion about the role of women in the Middle East.

item.title: U.S. Drops Its Case Against M.I.T. Scientist Accused of Hiding China Links

item.media:description: Gang Chen, an M.I.T. scientist, was arrested in 2021 as part of the China Initiative, a government anti-espionage effort that has come under criticism for singling out scientists of Chinese heritage.

item.title: A New Map of the Sun’s Local Bubble

item.media:description: A coral reef resembling a bed of roses was discovered off the coast of Tahiti.

item.media:description: Chuck McGinley with his Nasal Ranger, a design inspired by the shape of the Haleakala volcano in Hawaii.

item.media:description: The Caldor fire in Eldorado National Forest near Pollock Pines, Calif., last year.
